GS24samanv_u:113: could be that it refers to “bhaṭurā/baṭurā” (from “bhaṭṭhā/bhaṭṭhi” 'kiln, oven'
GS24samanv_u:114: which, in turn, may be from “bhrasj“), a type of “nān“/bread commonly used in the
GS24samanv_u:115: Punjab-Jammu area, and that MW, etc. have not understood the nature of the
GS24samanv_u:116: eatable exactly. The same dictionaries explain “śikhariṇī” as a dish made of curds,
GS24samanv_u:117: sugar, and spices, but the obvious cognate “śikaraṇ” current in Marathi stands
GS24samanv_u:118: primarily for crushed bananas or plantain fruits mixed with milk and sugar'.; #22 Ś:
